title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the trend in the percentage of electricity produced using nuclear energy in France between 1980 and 1990, such as any of the following:

· The trend in the percentage of electricity generated by nuclear power in France increased significantly/exponentially/rapidly from 1980 to 1990.

· The percent change of electricity generated/produced by nuclear power in France increased by 215% (acceptable range is 140% to 290%).

· The percentage of electricity generated/produced by nuclear power in France increased from by approximately 50% (acceptable range is 43% to 57%).

· The percentage of electricity generated by nuclear power in France had an approximate three-fold increase (acceptable range is 2.5 to 3.5 times) from 1980 to 1990.

The response describes the trend in the percentage of electricity produced using nuclear energy in France between 1980 and 1990, such as one of the following:

· The trend in the percentage of electricity generated by nuclear power in France increased significantly/exponentially/rapidly from 1980 to 1990.

· The percent change of electricity generated/produced by nuclear power in France increased by 215% (acceptable range is 140% to 290%).

· The percentage of electricity generated/produced by nuclear power in France increased from by approximately 50% (acceptable range is 43% to 57%).

· The percentage of electricity generated by nuclear power in France had an approximate three-fold increase (acceptable range is 2.5 to 3.5 times) from 1980 to 1990.

title: Part B

descriptions:

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how the United States could have used more nuclear fuel than Germany when the graph is showing similar trends for both countries such as the following:

· The graph is comparing percent, not total electricity production. The United States generated more electricity/used more energy than Germany in the 1990s.Therefore more nuclear fuel was required to produce the proportion of electricity produced by nuclear power plants in the United States.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim based on evidence that supports or refutes the statement that the 2011 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami in Japan had a positive impact on nuclear power generation in Japan after the event such as the following:

· The graph shows a very steep decline (from over 20% to nearly 0%) after 2011, refuting the claim that the Tohoku earthquake and tsunami had a positive impact on nuclear power generation.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one way increasing the amount of vegetation in cities can lead to decreased runoff, such as any of the following:

· Green roofs/urban forests/urban gardens/sidewalk trees allow water to infiltrate/percolate into the soil and slow/decrease runoff.

· Increased vegetation assimilates and stores more water leading to less runoff.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one cultural benefit that may result from increasing the amount of vegetation in cities, such as any of the following:

· Ability to visit natural places improves mental and physical health.

· Provision of food for harvesting and consumption.

· Improved attitudes of citizenry because of green spaces to gather as a community.
